column28: describe_teacher
column29: teachers_trustworthy
column30: distrust_teachers

column28: First grade when I was taught by my favorite teacher I have ever had. She made me feel like I could be honest about things.
column29: It put me on the track toward trusting my teachers in the future.
column30: N/A

I used to receive special treatment from my art teacher in early elementary school (the 64 box of crayons, an entire table to myself, tons of paper, etc). I told her one day that I was nowhere near as good as my brother. She asked who my brother was, and when I told her, immediately she became cold to me and never gave me special treatment again.

column28: Going to teachers when I had a family death
column29: At a young age I learned to confide in teachers and developed a trusting relationship with them
column30:
Professors who I have thought I liked and trusted, who brought forth bias in attempting to get students to turn on their colleagues (other professors I’ve had) ex: swaying students to avoid taking other professors’ classes, bashing other professors’ teaching methods 

Led to distrust of certain professors’ intentions and agenda

column28: The first time I truly trusted a teacher was in second or third grade when my teacher and my school counselor helped me with the anxiety I was feeling about my parents going out of town on vacation
column29: This experience made me perceive teachers and other school administrators not only as trustworthy but also as approachable, willing to help, and having my best interest in mind. I did not feel brushed off nor did I feel that their advice wasn’t helpful
column30: A few poor teachers that I had in middle school sometimes acted two-faced. They would say and act one way around the students and another way around administrators and parents.

column28: Kindergarten, following and accepting where teacher instructed me to sit in the classroom.
column29: Because of this experience of listening and following the instruction and experiencing the good things which came from it, I trust that teachers know what they are doing and have my best interest in mind.
column30: I have experienced this with a teacher who on the first day of class gave a very one sided account in a discussion, asked for student participation, then I gave my counter-example to his argument, and he pulled up an entire powerpoint with the purpose of attacking my argument. Essentially that he had prepped for a debate-like discussion while it was the first day so students did not have the opportunity to prepare, and the teacher was the one attacking my position rather than other students.

column28: In third grade when I became close enough with a teacher to watch her kids.
column29: It made me see her as a mother and a person outside the classroom and therefore more real.
column30: Anytime I have a teacher I perceive as bad (uncaring, disinterested, etc).

column28: In 2nd grade for reading I picked a book that had some difficult subject matter because it was about the atomic bombs that were dropped in Japan. It wasn't a hard reading level per se, but I remember my teacher talking to me about it and that if I wanted to talk to her more about what happened in the book I should because it can be hard to understand.
column29: I think it showed me that she wasn't trying to control what I was reading but also wanted to help me understand in my own time and need for more information about a difficult subject.
column30: In kindergarten, I remember on one of the last days of school we were going through everyone's first drawings of themselves as a class. My teacher would hold up each picture and I am sure she made comments about all of them but I remember her saying that I could use to lose a few based on my first drawing. Which as basically a snowman version of a kid, but I was probably five when I drew it, so the rude comment about my drawing made me less confident about my artwork going forward in school.

column28: Talking to my first grade teacher about my parents divorce
column29: Teachers care about you as a person not just as a student

column28: I think my earliest memory of truly trusting a teacher is my first day of Kindergarten. I am the oldest child, and I was very shy. I was incredibly nervous for my first day. My class met in the common area at school to walk to class, and my teacher held my hand as we walked to class.
column29: I felt loved and important in that moment. I feel like it set me up to view teachers as good people who care about me.
column30: I did not trust one teacher specifically who was always very crabby and yelled at everyone. I was quiet and always got my work done, but she would take her anger and frustration of a few kids to the entire class. I learned I could not trust her judgment or perception because I knew I did not deserve to be yelled at.

column28: The earliest memory of me truly trusting a teacher was in high school when I shared vulnerable things about myself to them.
column29: I knew that the teacher was listening and paying attention to me and gave good advice.
column30: When I’ve heard teachers being racist, misogynistic, or homophobic which has lead me to distrust teachers in the past.

column28: My science teacher in middle school would occasionally allow us to get completely off topic from class and ask any questions we had about anything. Her doing so allowed for lots of trust and connection between her and my class.
column29: It showed me that teachers truly just want to help everyone continue learning, questioning, and being curious.
column30: I have not experienced this at all but one way that could achieve distrust would be disclosing information to others (parents, other school officials) that was not meant to be shared

column28: I feel like I have always trusted them because they are in a higher position of authority.
column29: Since they are educators, I feel that they should be trustworthy.
column30: If they are unfriendly or mean, I tend to not trust them as much.

column28: At about age 10 or 11 my parents got a divorce and lived in different houses so I went between them everyday. My teacher at the time would ask who’s house I was at that night just to be correct in her sentence saying “give this to (mom/dad) to _______“ (to sign, read etc whatever was needed to be done). I thought this was very caring that she did this and definitely was something that makes me trust her (I don’t know if I realized it at the time but I definitely would trust her today if I still kept in contact with her)
column29: Little things can be important in the trust that I give any teacher. Trust can be earned through situations like these. Trust shouldnt be expected from all teachers just because they’re teachers.
column30: Although it was a joke, in 7th or 8th grade we were learning about the earths shape and how globes are used to portray maps in a sphere because it’s the easiest to see, but not being the world is a sphere. Of course the whole class was SO skeptical but after awhile, we all believed that the world wasn’t a sphere and that it was a flattened circle (like a pancake). With our new lesson, our teacher had some of us go around to tell admin and teachers (who had planned to be in the hall) about the actual shape of the world. When we came back the teacher laughed so hard and told us the adults in the hall were in on the joke... as silly as it was this made me loose some trust, not a lot. I definitely learned from it though.

column28: Middle school, I had a teacher tell me they were worried about me and it was the first time I’d had an interaction like that.
column29: Before then I did not trust teachers at all, just took them as knowledge boxes who were supposed to copy
column30: I’ve had teachers twist words to shift narratives , that really sucked because then no one believed me.

column28: Talking with my 8th grade math teaching about struggling with math previously
column29: He was the first math teacher who made me feel good at math and didn’t really judge me at all when he saw I was struggling. It didn’t really change my views surrounding other teachers though.
column30: In high school when I would submit my homework late they would sometimes lose it. Then accuse me of not actually turning it in. When I told them I did turn it in they would lecture me about how I’m not their only student and how they talk to tons of students everyday.

column28: In 6th grade, I had a teacher that I really, truly trusted. I was heavily bullied in middle school because I was overweight and not athletic, and I felt like I could really tell this teacher what I was going through. He also always had my back and stuck up for me when kids were being mean to me, which was not the case for my other teachers. One time I used my phone in my math class (which was taught my a different teacher) to tell my mom that I wanted to come home because people were making fun of me because I was crying due to my dog dying. The second teacher took away my phone and wouldn’t let me go to the office to call my mom, and he told me to “suck it up”. When the teacher I trusted found out, he got my phone and gave it back to me and let me go home without making a big deal out of it.
column29: I always saw this teacher as the exception and not the rule. When I graduated, he was the only teacher I thanked.
column30:
I have had terrible experiences with teachers. My school did not give us any sort of break, so I was never able to take vacation when I was younger. One time I tried to go visit my grandma for a week, and my science teacher told me I could spend time with my family and fail the class or come to school. She would not let me work ahead or make up the work. 

I had another teacher tell me that I was too stupid to go to college (I had a 4.0 GPA and was already taking college classes).

My worst experience was with a teacher that accused me of cheating, and then when the principal asked him why he accused me, he told the principal that “girls couldn’t be smart enough to get A’s”.

column28: After admitting halfway through a semester that I had done no homework, my teacher got angry with me. He said that I can’t just expect to do no work and get a passing grade (I do very well on tests). At that time I was upset, but I later understood that he probably was trying to change my behavior for the better.
column29: I now see that teachers can be quite emotional too, even if many keep a cool head on the outside. Recognizing humanity and common traits helps build connections, and con sections build trust.

column28: Probably in 3rd grade. Before then I trusted my teachers because that's what I was taught to do, but in 3rd grade I trusted my teacher because we built a trustworthy relationship. A girl lied and got me in trouble for being mean to her and I got brought in for detention. I told my teacher my side of the story and she believed me.
column29: It made me trust her, but not other teachers
column30: yes, teachers who say racist remarks

column28: In kindergarten, trusting that my teacher would help me keep track of my stuff
column29: reinforced my belief that adults (especially older women) could help me
column30: As I got older I learned that teachers are human, and sometimes you have to use your best judgement to determine whether the things they say are true (my 8th grade health teacher told us that the sandwich meat at Arby's is shipped as a liquid and then somehow solidified, which has been debunked many times)

column28: My fourth grade teacher was honest with you about every situation and would discipline appropriately, which a lot of people found harsh for children but I thought it was a very real experience kids need to have to have consequences for their actions
column29: After this I viewed at how “real” teachers were, if they wouldn’t sugar coat things I would trust them more
column30: One teacher I had in high school would get inappropriately involved in people’s personal life so I would watch what I said around her

column28: Telling my 3rd grade teacher my dog ate my homework.
column29: It did not.
column30: They don’t have answers on the subject they are teaching.

column28: 2nd grade teacher had a tradition of having student to her house around Christmas time and doing a gift exchange & cookie decorating while sharing stories about ourselves. She made us feel safe & comfortable so we were all able to have fun
column29: She showed me that people with authority can be down to earth & understanding.
column30: N/A

column28: When I was a sophomore in high school, I had to explain to my history teacher that I did not complete the homework from the night before because one of my childhood friends had committed suicide that night. It was very difficult to explain but I knew that I could trust her because she had always been so open and caring with us.
column29: Most teachers I have met truly love their job and want their students to succeed both in and outside the classroom. These teachers are very open about their willingness to help students and make an effort to connect with them one-on-one.
column30: I have not had a teacher that I outright distrusted, but there have been a few teachers who I did not connect well with and would not be at the top of my list for people I could go to if I needed help.

column28: I first truly trusted a teacher when I was a junior in highschool. Before this I had never shared personal struggles with a teacher but this teacher had noticed my off behavior in the previous weeks and asked what was going on.... I then preceded to fully trust this teacher with personal information.
column29: It showed me that teachers care a lot more than I originally thought. Being a teenager/young adult is difficult and having teachers that genuinely care for our health, safety and education was something I didn’t realize until this moment.
column30: I have had a few teachers over the years bash generation Z or use their power and position to back their political stand and that has caused me to distance myself or build a wall that would’ve enabled me to fully trust them.

column28: 5th grade.  Had home problems, which involved the school therapist and CPS being contacted.  My teacher asked me to stay after school for a minute to talk to me.
column29: It made me realize they had a larger role than just helping us through the day, and being a "teacher"
column30: was accused of cheating in a class (2nd grade) the teacher never took a side but it still affected my thought process about teachers for some time.

column28: I remember thinking I knew I could trust my kindergarten teacher because of how well she treated my family.
column29: I think it made me think that I can only trust the people around me do.
column30: I never really trusted my teachers who wouldn’t pick on other students because I didn’t want them to pick on me

column28: I have felt safe and looked up to my teachers from an early age. In first grade I let one of my teachers pull a loose tooth out!
column29: I trust their opinions and see them as a resource for any help I may need.
column30: Not really.

column28: I can’t remember a lot but I remember calling my teacher mom in 6th grade, so I guess that means I trusted her?
column29: I was embarrassed but realized teachers could be like family and reliable.
column30: When teachers say they’re going to grade easy but I do poorly on an assignment, I feel like I can’t really trust what they say.

column28: Trusty to disclose personal relationship issues and ask their advice.
column29: It created a better bond that I could trust them and actually rely on them if needed.
column30: n/a

column28: My only memory is in college, with my advisor. She has made it very clear that I can come to her with anything, and I have before.
column29: I trust my professors within my department, because they know me the best.
column30: I was ridiculed by 3 teachers once when I was in 4th grade, and that really tanked my perception of teachers at the time.

column28: In high school as a sophomore I had an English teacher who spoke about personal opinions often and welcomed challenges from students in topics related and unrelated to class.  His candor and openness to variability of opinion and approach made me feel like he understood topics well.  His was the first class that I felt like I critically thought about things.
column29: Transparency and an openness to discuss things are things that make me trust teachers.  If they don’t engage in these behaviors, I find it harder to engage with and trust
column30: Being reluctant to explain decisions and take criticism are both obvious and lead to an inhibited ability to trust

column28: In fourth grade I was writing a story about talking cars. I went to my teacher and asked her how to spell the word Porsche. She told me that she did not know how to spell the word, but she gave me her best guess at the spelling. I appreciated that she didn’t pretend to be more knowledgeable than she was, and she admitted when she didn’t k is something.
column29: Some people feel like they need to have answers to any question that is asked of them. But in my experience, teachers know that it is impossible for them to know everything a student may ask them. I have had many teachers who are honest when they don’t know something and help the student find the answer so they can both learn together.
column30: My brother had a teacher who lied to him and my parents. She told them that my brother had never turned in an assignment and she found it in his locker. However, my brother (a third grader at the time) told my parents that she had lost his assignment and he remembered turning it in. The teacher thought she could get away with her dishonesty because of my brothers young age, rather than honestly owning up to her mistake.

column28: High school — I was physically ill and a teacher took time out of their day to sit down with me privately to make sure I was doing okay
column29: Positively - made me felt like I was cared about and noticed in a large academic setting
column30: No

column28: when my parents got divorced in second grade, my teacher gave me the class chinchilla to take home over Christmas break and told me I could talk to her about anything going on with my parents because she had experienced it too. I knew I could trust her because of her vulnerability with me!
column29:
'- made me see her outside of just being a teacher
- showed me she had my best interests at heart, and I could trust her
column30: I had a teacher in middle school who had a blatant favorite in the class. The girl she liked the most and I didn't really get along, and the teacher would make passive-aggressive remarks about me in front of the class. I felt like her and the girl would talk about me behind my back...don't know if that's true, but I certainly did not trust either of them

column28: In 3rd grade my teacher allowed me to go into the hall because I would get too distracted during “rocket math” this allowed me to trust that my teacher truly wanted the best for me.
column29: I trusted that my teacher would take my struggles into consideration and help me become a successful student.
column30: In middle school a teacher went and told my other teachers how poorly I was doing in class. I had recently lost my father and was struggling with my mental health. She then called a meeting with multiple teachers and myself to basically call me out on not turning in assignments.

column28: I trusted my 2nd grade teacher who was kind and tutored me in Spanish after school as well
column29: It did not to my knowledge
column30: N/A

column28: Trusting Mr. Wallin in 6th grade with things that I was thinking or having a hard time with.
column29: It made me want to have more male teachers in high school and middle school. It made me seek out advice from the more male teachers after that
column30: When teachers don't open up about their life or are very introverted close minded or are as creepy as Mr. Fredine, or mr.hemmeelin, from rahs.

column28: none, I've never been close to a teacher

When I got hurt in 2nd grade in school at recess. My parents were getting a divorce and while I wasn't actively aware I knew something wasn't right. She was helpful and told me that she'd help me to the nurse but also said that she'd always be there no matter what was going on at home.
column29: It led me to be more trusting of teachers at a younger age but I still struggle with trusting everyone completely.
column30: High school, 11th grade precalculus with trig. I struggled in class and so did one of my good friends at the time. I struggled and passed with a 72% but she went to him and got him to bump her grade to an 80 from a 73 by helping run some church activities. When I approached the teacher about out for how it was inappropriate as it wasn't extra credit offered the whole class and was religious based at a public high school I was told "it's a Christian thing, anyone that goes to church could get the opportunity" but as someone nonreligious I was excluded simply due to my religion. While I knew some people and teachers weren't trustworthy that was the first time I'd explicitly been shown and impacted. (And yes I did report it and no, nothing came about from it)

column28: I don’t think I have ever truly trusted a teacher.
column29: I just don’t think I would be comfortable enough to divulge private information.
column30: No

column28: In third grade we did an overnight camp and I had bedwetting and I had to tell them in a form. They didn't mention it and I was fine, but it was nice to know that they didn't tell any other kids in my grade because I would be nervous they would make fun of me.
column29: I realized that sometimes teachers just don't care and there are probably other students that go through similar things. Because of this positive experience, I began to trust teachers more throughout my life.
column30: My teacher showed me a photo of his dead cat and I thought that was a little weird.

column28: Being able to talk through my personal health struggles with a teacher early in high school. I know I trusted teachers before this, but didn’t have specific memories.
column29: It increased my trust, as the teacher was able to give me the support I needed.
column30: I had a teacher who lost assignments I had previously turned in, and then refused to help me in understanding the content because I “didn’t put the work in”.

column28: Early high school art teacher; was very kind and laid back, along with always listening and supporting his students no matter if the subject involved the class or if it was related to their own personal lives.
column29: This helped me gain the perspective that teachers are just people too. Teaching is just their occupation, they all have their own personalities and traits that sometimes are more heavily shown in the classroom which can cause students to take a liking or trust them more (assuming their personalities and traits are positive).
column30: Personally, I have never had a distrusting experience with a teacher but if I were to distrust a teacher it would be if I needed to communicate something to them (school or personal related) and they belittled me or made me feel like my issue is not a priority to them.

column28: My third grade teacher was very understanding and flexible with me because of my learning disability
column29: It impacted me because my teacher did not judge me for my ability to learn and how I learned differently and did what she could to help me. She did not leave me behind
column30: A teacher of mine once said my learning disability was not her problem or concern

column28: Asking for letters of recommendation.
column30: Never had one.

column28: I haven't had any teachers that I would consider untrustworthy until college and that is only because they taught me incorrect information leading me to distrust their expertise. Throughout elementary, middle, and high school, however, I have trusted my teachers.
column29: I, for the most part, trust teachers that I come into contact with.
column30: The only situations in which I distrusted teachers are when they taught me something that I knew to be false.

column28: Any teacher that has come up to me after my parents sent an email and they wanted to check in with me
column29: I know they’re good people and I can hopefully trust them with personal info

column28: I have always believed my teachers to be trusting, therefore I cannot say I have specific memory that I mark as the earliest I remember trusting a teacher. Since elementary school, I have trusted my teachers not only in their teaching methods, but also in the knowledge they impart on me. That being said, I still like to do research on my own, especially when their are differing perspectives.
column29: As mentioned before, I have always trusted my teachers and cannot recall a specific memory that marks the beginning of my trusting of teachers.
column30: There was one incident my senior year in which my English teacher, who was one of my favorite teachers, informed us of the words of a politician (not the president) and incorrectly quoted that politician, making what the politician said seem really bad even though what they actually said could be interpreted in many  different (and less negative) ways. In this instance, my teacher’s political bias came through and caused her to feed her students false information, which can be dangerous as students are taught to trust the words of their teachers. This did not cause me to distrust my English teacher, or any other teacher for that matter, but it did make me more aware of how sometimes we need to research things for ourself.

column28: A teacher advised us about focusing on learning the material in the class rather than worrying about grades.
column29: It was a type of advice my parents will give to me.
column30: My teacher sharing my grades with another teacher.

column28: Probably kindergarten. Bringing my teacher a present for Christmas or something. Nothing has really happened where I feel as though, yes I can fully trust them or no I fully cannot trust them.
column29: It didn't. I don't view teachers as trustworthy or untrustworthy.
column30: None.

column28: The earliest moment in which I trusted a teacher was in third grade. I was going through some family difficulties and trusted her with that information. Not only did this teacher keep this information to herself, but went out of her way to make sure I was alright and performing and completing tasks on time and fully.
column29: This experience enabled me to realize that numerous teachers really do want what's best for their students and are there to support and help them in whatever ways they can to ensure success.
column30: I have not had an experience where I have felt like I distrust a teacher completely. The only instance I can think of is when I found out a teacher was gossiping about other students. I would definitely not want to confide in or trust someone who does that.

column28: In high school, I was going through a rough patch. I was not able to live with either of my parents due to on of my parent's alcoholism. I was living with friends, changing houses often. My Spanish teacher noticed some changes in my personality. She reached out to me and I told her what had been going on. She became a great confidant and helped me stay motivated in school.
column29: This experience changed how I viewed teachers. I used to think they were just people who had to give students homework and didn't necessarily always care like they should. Now I see that they can be trustworthy adult figures for kids. I never really trusted a teacher enough to tell them about my home life, but having one teacher that noticed really made a difference.
column30: I have not had an experience that lead me to distrust a teacher.

column28: In first grade, I still didn't know how to tie my shoes. It was embarassing as a kid to not know how to do something almost everyone else knew. I remember my teacher saying that she wasn't going to help us tie shoes because that was something that kindergartners should have learned and we are older now. I had my shoes untied during school one day and she helped me. She said it was the only time she would completely do it for me, but if I need help she'll show me what to do next time.
column29: It showed me that if I needed help, I could trust my teacher to help me.
column30: I had a teacher in high school that would read aloud everyone's test grade and have some type of reaction to it. I remember once I didn't do so well and he reacted negatively. I think everyone in the class felt weird about that.

column28: When I told a teacher some personal problems that I was having in my house.
column29: I started believing that you can really trust teachers sometimes.
column30: When I don't really like teachers attitudes I don't really trust them

column28: My earliest moment of truly trusting a teacher was in 7th grade when I met my teacher who helped me through one of my toughest decisions. He never made it about the two things I was choosing between, but instead he made it about me and what I wanted to do to make myself happy.
column29: I knew he cared about me and my wellbeing. He made me feel like I was a real person and could choose what I wanted instead of people making the decision for me. Ever since then I trusted him.
column30: I would say I have not yet experienced a situation which lead me to distort a teacher. I would say the teacher I described above is the only real teacher I have had who I trusted.

column28: I was going through a lot of mental health issues with both of my parents having cancer, and I remember I had to retake a test after school in high school. I really liked the teacher I had for that class, and he asked me about my personal life (he really liked me as a student too) and I opened up to him about some of the struggles I had been going through with depression and anxiety disorders.
column29: He was really supportive and appreciative of me for telling him what I did as well as continuing to try my best in school. It felt good to be validated by a teacher so I remember I always trusted him after that.
column30: Nothing specific but I usually am not trusting of adult males in general.

column28: My Kindergarten teacher was such a sweet person and I truly trusted her because of her kindness.
column29: It made me have a better perception of teachers and made me more trusting.
column30: One of my teachers in Middle School was fired for sexual harrassment of a student.

column28: The teacher I had in 1st and 2nd grade was someone I felt like I could trust if the situation came that I needed to confide in her. She was just overall kind, patient, and understanding. I never felt like she was looking down on me or patronizing me for anything I struggled with.
column29: I usually see teachers as people I can trust, especially if they are kind and understanding. But I feel like that foes for anyone - if someone is kind and understanding, they will seem trustworthy, teachers included.
column30: A few teachers I had in high school always seemed annoyed or irritated when I came to them after-hours for help. They seemed mad that I did not understand the content I was learning in their class, and frustrated with me when I did not comprehend right away. Experiences like that with them made me feel like I couldn't safely ask them for help, which made me feel like I couldn't trust them

column28: Being in accelerated math in elementary school the teacher we worked with would take us aside and discuss our strengths and weaknesses and what we should work on and I felt like I could trust that she cared about my academic success
column29: It just made me more aware of how teachers are looking out for students
column30: Yes, heard teacher gossiping about my classmates so I became weary of what I said around her

column28: In kindergarten, my teacher was very understanding that I was shy and that it was hard for me to be in school all day. She would be nice to me and make me feel at ease and not force me to do anything that I didn't want to do.
column29: I learned that teachers are understanding and they can help out. This also helped lessen my fear of authority figures because I saw them as more relate-able
column30: I don't think there has been any instances where teachers have been untrustworthy.

column28: I would probably say my 7th grade history teacher.  I was pretty indifferent about my teachers up until that point
column29: It didn’t really impact it.  I’ve never thought of teachers as untrustworthy, it’s just I hadn’t really trusted one fully until then
column30: I haven’t really

column28: In Kindergarten, I had the most amazing teacher. I remember playing with Legos in her classroom, and feeling very safe knowing I was her responsibility.
column29: I think this experience made me initially perceive all teachers as trustworthy until proven otherwise.
column30: In first grade, my teacher yelled at a girl sitting in my pod because she was whining. It scared the crap out of me. Also, after my teacher yelled at the girl, the girl cried even harder and threw up because she was so distressed. From that day on, I was a little scared to go back to class because I didn't want my teacher to yell at me.

column28: In 7th grade my English teacher was like my therapist
column29: I knew that specific teach was more open and kind towards students but most teachers aren’t like that
column30: Yeah many time. They always made promises they never kept.

column28: I had a really good relationship with my second grade teacher. She allowed me to really express myself and that helped me trust her later on.
column29: I had a favorable view of teachers after this experience.
column30: One time a guidance counselor (kind of different than a teacher) yelled at me for not sharing confidential information with her.

column28: In first grade, I was nervous to sing in front of my class and my teacher Mrs. York made me feel comfortable and confident and told me that she would be right next to me during the whole thing and I felt like I could always trust her from then on.
column29: This made me always trust teachers at first until they prove to be untrustworthy.
column30: I had a teacher who made fun of me to other classmates for not being as good at math and that made me lose all trust in her.

column28: My earliest memory of truly trusting a teacher was when I was in 5th grade when I went to her about being bullied by one of my classmates. She was the first one that I told.
column29: It made me feel more comfortable with teachers but since she was a one year teacher unlike middle school and high school, we didn’t fully make a lasting connection of trust. When I was a 10th grade, I became extremely close with a teacher who I still talk to today on the regular.
column30: On teacher that I trusted very well went behind my bad to talk to another teacher about me after I broke down while aiding for her. While it was the right thing for her to do because I was not in the right mental status and needed help, she shouldn’t have taken what I had shared with her an brought it to one of my other teachers.

column28: I can’t think of a time I have ever completely trusted a teacher.
column29: I think that I have never trusted teachers because I like to keep my personal life separate from my school life.

column28: 4th grade teacher, we became really close and she always supported me and made me feel like I could actually achieve something. In highschool I then did some volunteering for her and we stayed in touch.
column29: This experience made me realize that most teachers truly care about their students and they want them to succeed. I think I also broke out of my shell a little and became more outspoken and talkative with my teachers.
column30: I can’t think of anything in particular.

column28: In sixth grade, we were not technically allowed to eat food when we were not in the lunchroom. However, I have quite a small stomach, and our grade had to eat lunch last every day. I would get very hungry around 11am, and after explaining to my Latin teacher that I was having a hard time focusing in his class (around 11) because I was always so hungry, he allowed me to discreetly have a snack whenever I needed to. Even when I accidentally spilled a bag of goldfish on the floor, which is something he should have written me up and given me a detention for (that was the rule for being caught eating in class, and I clearly broke his rule about being discreet), he continued to allow me to have snacks. This may seem like a really small thing, but it showed me that he was on my side and I could trust him to show me kindness and compassion.
column29: This experience showed me that many teachers will bend the rules if you are a good student and looking for a rule-bend for a good reason- teachers are not simply mindless robots that follow everything admin says. Having that trust helped me out many times in high school, when I had much bigger issues than just a spilled bag of goldfish.
column30: My music teacher in 7th grade told me about how a lot of the teachers would basically gossip about students, trying to guess which ones were "dating" or which friends were fighting. I had never thought about teachers paying that close attention to our personal lives, and it made me super self conscious about my interactions with my friends and my "boyfriend" at the time. I am positive he told me that because he thought I would be amused by it, but it horrified me to known that many of my teachers could be talking about me behind my back- even the ones I liked a lot.

column28: In elementary school, I was put into the speech class and I didn't feel comfortable doing so because it made it feel like there was something wrong with me. My teacher talked to me and communicated with me about it to make me feel more comfortable with going and that there was nothing wrong with it. They made me feel like it was okay to be in speech and that if anything went wrong they would be there to help.
column29: It made me view teachers as people who are willing to help you.
column30: In middle school I had an art teacher yell at me and tell me that I was going to fail his class since I had to leave early every day to go to track practice at the high school. It was already communicated with counselors and both of the teachers it would be effecting (including the art teacher) of why I would miss and that it was okay for me to miss part of class. I lost trust in him because he knew the reason why I was leaving every day and I finished all of my projects before they were due but he singled me out in front of the class to say what a bad student I was.

column28: I was in second grade and needed help with a school bully. I talked to my teacher knowing she would understand and help. She talked through it with me and helped me talk to the bully about my feelings.
column29: I saw it as a positive experience, and was able to go to teachers for help in the future.
column30: I had one teacher in highschool that got a substitute reprimanded for political conversation in the classroom and she then later that week did the same thing herself for the opposite political party.

column28: Honestly, I can't really recall a time where I've truly trusted a teacher with some aspect of my personal life. It's not that I distrusted any of them, but it never really went past a professional student-teacher type of relationship. If I have to give an answer then I would say the teacher I had the closest connection to was my 11th grade history teacher. He was a younger instructor so he had the ability to relate to the kids more than the other instructors - he understood pop culture references, he was able to make genuinely funny jokes, and every now and then he would discuss a little of his personal life. He seemed to be truly interested in what students did and liked which made him an easy person to get along with. Again, I don't know if this counts as trusting, but it's a connection nonetheless.
column29: I was always able to understand that teachers are people, but he really helped me to understand how much of a person he actually was. Since he was able to relate to us as young people (not just students) we were able to see him as a man (not just a teacher).
column30: I remember this one instance in which an instructor I had years ago was let go from his teaching position because he sent somewhat inappropriate emails to a few students. To be very clear, they were not absurdly obscene, but they were questionable. The situation as a whole just made me confused and wanted him to be okay since it didn't seem like him.

column28: In 1st grade, I remember going back to see my kindergarten teacher every single day and telling her about my day because I trusted her.
column29: I felt that I could trust most teachers and that they were there to help us.
column30: I know people who are teachers now and they admit that they talk about other students with each other.

column28: I remember opening up a lot to my 5th grade teacher.
column29: She was so kind and caring and I thought of her as more of a parental figure than just a teacher.
column30: Sometimes teachers will put trick questions on exams.

column28: Probably in first grade I remember my teacher being so nice and it wasnt scary to talk to her
column29: Ive always trusted my teachers, but I havent really gotten personal with any of them

column28: I feel like I have been able to trust every teacher/professor I've had, so I don't really have an earliest memory of trusting a specific teacher.
column29: N/A
column30: Nothing I can remember, I have been fortunate enough to have had very trusting teachers in my past.
